stanza.line: When my Loue ſweares that ſhe is made of truth,
I dœ beleeue her (though I know ſhe lies)
That ſhe might thinke me ſome vntutor’d youth,
Vnskilfull in the worlds falſe forgeries.
Thus vainly thinking that ſhe thinkes me young,
Although I know my yeares be paſt the beſt:
I ſmiling, credite her falſe ſpeaking toung,
Outfacing faults in Loue, with loues ill reſt.
But wherefore ſayes my Loue that ſhe is young?
And wherefore ſay not I, that I am old?
O, Loues beſt habite is a ſoothing toung,
And Age (in Loue) loues not to haue yeares told.

couplet.line: Therefore Ile lye with Loue, and Loue with me,
Since that our faults in Loue thus ſmother’d be.

stanza.line: Two Loues I haue, of Comfort, and Deſpaire,
That like two Spirits, do ſuggeſt me ſtill:
My better Angell is a Man (right faire)
My worſer ſpirite a Woman (colour’d ill.)
To winne me ſoone to hell, my Female euill
Tempteth my better Angell from my ſide,
And would corrupt my Saint to be a Diuell,
Wooing his purity with her faire pride.
And whether that my Angell be turnde feend,
Suſpeƈt I may (yet not direƈtly tell:
For being both to me: both, to each friend,
I gheſſe one Angell in anothers hell:

couplet.line: The truth I ſhall not know, but liue in doubt,
Till my bad Angell ﬁre my good one out.

stanza.line: Did not the heauenly Rhetorike of thine eie,
Gainſt whom the world could not hold argumēt,
Perſwade my hart to this falſe periurie:
Vowes for thee broke deſerue not puniſhment.
A woman I forſwore: but I will proue
Thou being a Goddeſſe, I forſwore not thee:
My vow was earthly, thou a heauenly loue,
Thy grace being gainde, cures all diſgrace in me.
My vow was breath, and breath a vapor is,
Then thou faire Sun, that on this earth doth ſhine,
Exhale this vapor vow, in thee it is:
If broken, then it is no fault of mine.

couplet.line: If by me broke, what foole is not ſo wiſe
To breake an Oath, to win a Paradiſe?

stanza.line: Sweet Cytherea, ſitting by a Brooke,
With young Adonis, louely, freſh and greene,
Did court the Lad with many a louely looke,
Such lookes as none could looke but beauties queen.
She told him ſtories, to delight his eares.
She ſhew’d him fauors, to allure his eie:
To win his hart, ſhe toucht him here and there,
Touches ſo ſoﬅ ſtill conquer chaſtitie.
But whether vnripe yeares did want conceit,
Or he refuſde to take her ﬁgured proffer,
The tender nibler would not touch the bait,
But ſmile, and ieaſt, at euery gentle offer:

couplet.line: Then fell ſhe on her backe, faire queen, & toward
He roſe and ran away, ah foole too froward.

stanza.line: If Loue make me forſworn, how ſhal I ſwere to loue?
O, neuer faith could hold, if not to beauty vowed:
Though to my ſelfe forſworn, to thee Ile conſtant proue,
thoſe thoghts to me like Okes, to thee like Oſiers bowed.
Studdy his byas leaues, and makes his booke thine eies,
where all thoſe pleaſures liue, that Art can comprehend:
If knowledge be the marke, to know thee ſhall ſufﬁce:
Wel learned is that toung that well can thee commend,
All ignorant that ſoule, that ſees thee without wonder,
Which is to me ſome praiſe, that I thy parts admyre:
Thine eye loues lightning ſeems, thy voice his dreadfull thunder
which (not to anger bent) is muſick & ſweet ﬁre.

couplet.line: Celeſtiall as thou art, O, do not loue that wrong:
To ſing heauens praiſe, with ſuch an earthly toung.

stanza.line: Scarſe had the Sunne dride vp the deawy morne,
And ſcarſe the heard gone to the hedge for ſhade:
When Cytherea (all in Loue forlorne)
A longing tariance for Adonis made
Vnder an Oſyer growing by a brooke,
A brooke, where Adon vſde to coole his ſpleene:
Hot was the day, ſhe hotter that did looke
For his approch, that oﬅen there had beene.
Anon he comes, and throwes his Mantle by,
And ſtood ſtarke naked on the brookes greene brim:
The Sunne look’t on the world with glorious eie,
Yet not ſo wiſtly, as this Queene on him:

couplet.line: He ſpying her, bounſt in (whereas he ſtood)
Oh love (quoth ſhe) why was not I a ﬂood?

stanza.line: Faire is my loue, but not ſo faire as fickle.
Milde as a Doue, but neither true nor truſtie,
Brighter than glaſſe, and yet as glaſſe is brittle,
Soﬅer than waxe, and yet as Iron ruſty:

couplet.line: A lilly pale, with damaske die to grace her,
None fairer, nor none falſer to deface her.

stanza.line: Her lips to mine how oﬅen hath ſhe ioyned,
Betweene each kiſſe her othes of true loue ſwearing:
How many tales to pleaſe me hath ſhe coyned,
Dreading my loue, the loſſe whereof ſtill fearing.

couplet.line: Yet in the mids of all her pure proteſtings,
Her faith, her othes, her teares, and all were ieaſtings.

stanza.line: She burnt with loue, as ſtraw with ﬁre ﬂameth,
She burnt out loue, as ſoone as ſtraw out burneth:
She framd the loue, and yet ſhe foyld the framing,
She bad loue laſt, and yet ſhe fell a turning.

couplet.line: Was this a louer, or a Letcher whether?
Bad in the beſt, though excellent in neither.

stanza.line: If Muſicke and ſweet Pœtrie agree,
As they muſt needs (the Siſter and the brother)
Then muſt the loue be great twixt thee and me,
Becauſe thou lou’ſt the one, and I the other.
Dowland to thee is deere, whoſe heauenly tuch
Vpon the Lute, dooth rauiſh humane ſenſe:
Spenſer to me, whoſe deepe Conceit is ſuch,
As paſsing all conceit, needs no defence.
Thou lou’ſt to heare the ſweet melodious ſound,
That Phœbus Lute (the Queene of Muſicke) makes;
And I in deepe Delight am chieﬂy drownd,
When as himſelfe to ſinging he betakes.

couplet.line: One God is God of both (as Pœts faine)
One Knight loues Both, and both in thee remaine.

stanza.line: Faire was the morne, when the faire Queene of loue,
Paler for ſorrow then her milke white Doue,
For Adoni ſake, a youngſter proud and wilde,
Her ſtand ſhe takes vpon a ſteepe vp hill.
Anon Adonis comes with horne and hounds;
She ſilly Queene, with more then loues good will,
Forbad the boy he ſhould not paſſe thoſe grounds,
Once (quoth ſhe) did I ſee a faire ſweet youth
Here in theſe brakes, deepe wounded with a Beare,
Deepe in the thigh a ſpeƈtacle of ruth,
Set in my thigh (quoth ſhe) here was the ſore.

couplet.line: She ſhewed hers, he ſaw more wounds than one,
And bluſhing ﬂed, and leﬅ her all alone.

stanza.line: Sweet Roſe, faire ﬂower, vntimely pluckt, ſoon vaded,
Pluckt in the bud, and vaded in the ſpring
Bright orient pearle, alacke too timely ſhaded,
Faire creature kilde too ſoon by Deaths ſharpe ſting:

couplet.line: Like a greene plumbe that hangs vpon a tree:
And fals (through winde) before the fall ſhould be.

stanza.line: I weepe for thee, and yet no cauſe I haue,
For why: thou leﬅs me nothing in thy will
And yet thou leﬅs me more than I did craue,
For why I craued nothing of thee ſtill;

couplet.line: O yes (deare friend I pardon craue of thee,
Thy diſcontent thou didſt bequeath to me.

stanza.line: Venus with Adonis ſitting by her,
Vnder a Mirtle ſhade began to woœ him,
She told the youngling how god Mars did trie her,
And as he fell to her, ſhe fell to him.
Euen thus (quoth ſhe) the warlike god embrac’t me:
And then ſhe clipt Adonis in her armes:
Euen thus (quoth ſhe) the warlike god vnlac’t me,
As if the boy ſhould vſe like louing charmes:
Euen thus (quoth ſhe) he ſeized on my lippes,
And with her lips on his did aƈt the ſeizure:
And as ſhe fetched breath, away he skips,
And would not take her meaning nor her pleaſure.

couplet.line: Ah, that I had my Lady at this bay:
To kiſſe and clip me till I run away.

stanza.line: Crabbed age and youth cannot liue together,
Youth is full of pleaſance, age is full of care,
Youth like ſummer morne, Age like winter weather,
Youth like ſummer braue, Age like winter bare.
Youth is full of ſport, Ages breath is ſhort,
Youth is nimble, Age is lame
Youth is hot and bold, Age is weake and cold,
Youth is wild, and Age is tame.

couplet.line: Age I dœ abhor thee, Youth I dœ adore thee,
O my loue my loue is young:
Age I dœ deﬁe thee. Oh ſweet Shepheard hie thee:
For me thinks thou ſtaies too long.

stanza.line: Beauty is but a vaine and doubtfull good,
A ſhining gloſſe, that vadeth ſodainly,
A ﬂower that dies, when ﬁrſt it gins to bud,
A brittle glaſſe, thats broken preſently.

couplet.line: A doubtfull good, a gloſſe, a glaſſe, a ﬂower,
Loſt, vaded, broken, dead within an houre.

stanza.line: And as goods loſt, are ſeld or neuer found,
As vaded gloſſe no rubbing will refreſh:
As ﬂowers dead, lie withered on the ground,
As broken glaſſe no ſymant can redreſſe.

couplet.line: So beauty blemiſht once, for euer loſt,
In ſpite of phiſicke, painting, paine and coſt.

stanza.line: Good night, good reſt, ah neither be my ſhare,
She bad good night, that kept my reſt away,
And daﬅ me to a cabben hangde with care:
To deſcant on the doubts of my decay.

couplet.line: Farewell (quoth ſhe) and come againe to morrow
Fare well I could not, for I ſupt with ſorrow.

stanza.line: Yet at my parting ſweetly did ſhe ſmile,
In ſcorne or friendſhip, nill I conſter whether:
’T may be ſhe ioyd to ieaſt at my exile,
’T may be againe, to make me wander thither.

couplet.line: Wander (a word) for ſhadowes like my ſelfe,
As take the paine but cannot plucke the pelfe.

stanza.line: Lord how mine eies throw gazes to the Eaſt,
My hart doth charge the watch, the morning riſe
Doth ſeite each mouing ſcence from idle reſt,
Not daring truſt the ofﬁce of mine eies.

couplet.line: While Philomela ſits and ſings, I ſit and mark,
And wiſh her layes were tuned like the larke.

stanza.line: For ſhe doth welcome daylight with her ditte,
And driues away darke dreaming night:
The night ſo packt, I poſt vnto my pretty,
Hart hath his hope, and eies their wiſhed ſight,

couplet.line: Sorrow changd to ſolace, and ſolace mixt with ſorrow,
For why, ſhe ſight, and bad me come to morrow.

stanza.line: Were I with her, the night would poſt too ſoone,
But now are minutes added to the houres:
To ſpite me now, ech minute ſeemes an houre,
Yet not for me, ſhine ſun to ſuccour ﬂowers.

couplet.line: Pack night, peep day, good day of night now borrow
Short night to night, and length thy ſelfe to morrow.

stanza.line: It was a Lordings daughter, the faireſt one of three
That liked of her maſter, as well as well might be,
Till looking on an Engliſhman, the faireſt that eie could ſee,

couplet.line: Her fancie fell a turning.

stanza.line: Long was the combat doubtfull, that loue with loue did ﬁght,
To leave the maſter loueleſſe, or kill the gallant knight:
To put in praƈtiſe either, alas it was a ſpite

couplet.line: Vnto the ſilly damſell.

stanza.line: But one muſt be refuſed, more mickle was the paine,
That nothing could be vſed, to turne them both to gaine,
For of the two the truſty knight was wounded with diſdain:

couplet.line: Alas, ſhe could not helpe it.

stanza.line: Thus art with armes contending, was viƈtor of the day,
Which by a giﬅ of learning, did beare the maid away,
Then lullaby the learned man hath got the Lady gay,

couplet.line: For now my ſong is ended.

stanza.line: On a day (alacke the day)
Loue whoſe month was euer May
Spied a bloſſome pasſing fair,
Playing in the wanton ayre,
Through the veluet leaues the wind
All unſeene gan paſſage ﬁnd,
That the louer (ſicke to death)
Wiſht himſelfe the heauens breath,
Ayre (quoth he) thy cheekes may blowe
Ayre, would I might triumph ſo
But (alas) my hand hath ſworne,
Nere to plucke thee from thy throne,
Vow (alacke) for youth vnmeet,
Youth, ſo apt to pluck a ſweet,
Thou for whome loue would ſweare,
Iuno but an Ethiope were
And deny hymſelfe for loue
Turning mortall for thy Loue.
My ﬂocks feede not, my Ewes breed not,
My Rams ſpeed not, all is amis:
Loue is dying, Faithes defying,

couplet.line: Harts nenying, cauſer of this.

stanza.line: All my merry ligges are quite forgot,
All my Ladies louers loſt (god wot)
Where her faith was ﬁrmely ﬁxt in loue,
There a nay is plac’t without remoue.

couplet.line: One ſilly croſſe, wrought all my loſſe,
O frowning fortune curſed ﬁckle dame,
For now I ſee, inconſtancy,
More in women then in men remaine.

stanza.line: In blacke morne I, all feares ſcorne I,
Loue hath forlorne me, liuing in thrall:
Hart is bleeding, all helpe needing,
O cruell ſpeeding, fraughted with gall.
My ſhepheards pipe can ſound no deale,
My weathers bell rings dolefull knell,
My curtaile dogge that wont to haue plaid,
Plaies not at all but ſeemes afraid.

couplet.line: With ſighes ſo deepe, procures to weepe,
In howling wiſe, to ſee my dolefull plight,
How ſighes reſound through hartles ground
Like a thouſand vanquiſht men in blodie ﬁght.

stanza.line: Cleare wels ſpring not, ſweete birds ſing not,
Greene plants bring not forth their die,
Heards ſtands weeping, ﬂocks all ſleeping,
Nimphes blacke peeping fearefully:
All our pleaſure knowne to vs poore ſwaines:
All our merrie meetings on the plaines,
All our euening ſport from vs is ﬂed,
All our loue is loſt, for loue is dead,

couplet.line: Farewell ſweet loue thy like nere was,
For a ſweet content the cauſe of all my wœ,
Poore Coridon muſt liue alone,
Other helpe for him I ſee that there is none.

stanza.line: When as thine eye hath choſe the Dame,
And ſtalde the deare that thou ſhouldſt ſtrike,
Let reaſon rule things worthy blame,
As well as fancy (partyall might)

couplet.line: Take counſell of ſome wiſer head,
Neither too young, nor yet vnwed.

stanza.line: And when thou comſt thy tale to tell,
Smooth not thy toung with ﬁled talke,
Leaſt ſhe ſome ſubtill praƈtiſe ſmell,
A Cripple ſoone can ﬁnde a halt,

couplet.line: But plainly ſay thou louſt her well,
And ſet her perſon forth to ſale.

stanza.line: What though her frowning browes be bent
Her cloudy lookes will calme yer night,
And then too late ſhe will repent,
That thus diſſembled her delight.

couplet.line: And twice deſire yer it be day,
That which with ſcorne ſhe put away.

stanza.line: What though ſhe ſtriue to try her ſtrength,
And ban and braule, and ſay the nay:
Her feeble force will yeeld at length,
When craﬅ hath taught her thus to ſay:

couplet.line: Had women beene ſo ſtrong as men
In faith you had not had it then.

stanza.line: And to her will frame all thy waies,
Spare not to ſpend, and chieﬂy there,
Where thy deſart may merit praiſe
By ringiug in thy Ladies eare,

couplet.line: The ſtrongeſt caſtle, tower and towne,
The golden bullet beats it downe.

stanza.line: Serue alwaies with aſſured truſt,
And in thy ſute be humble true,
Vnleſſe thy Lady proue vniuſt,
Preaſe neuer thou to chuſe a new:

couplet.line: When time ſhall ſerue, be thou not ſlacke,
To proffer thongh ſhe put thee back.

stanza.line: The wiles and guiles that women worke,
Diſſembled with an outward ſhew:
The tricks and toyes that in them lurke,
The Cock that trends thē ſhall not know,

couplet.line: Haue you not heard it ſaid full oﬅ,
A Womans nay doth ſtand for nought.

stanza.line: Thinke Women ſtill to ſtriue with men,
To ſinne and neuer for to ſaint,
There is no heauen (by holy then)
When time with age ſhall them attaint,

couplet.line: Were kiſſes all the ioyes in bed,
One woman would another wed.

stanza.line: But ſoﬅ enough, too much I feare,
Leaſt that my miſtreſſe heare my ſong,
She will not ſtick to round me on th’ are,
To teach my toung to be ſo long:

couplet.line: Yet will ſhe bluſh, here be it ſaid,
To heare her ſecrets ſo bewraid.

stanza.line: Liue with me and be my Loue,
And we will all the pleaſures proue
That hilles and vallies, dales and ﬁelds,
And all the craggy mountaines yeeld.
There will we ſit vpon the Rocks,
And ſee the Shepheards feed their ﬂocks,
By ſhallow Riuers, by whoſe fals
Melodious birds ſing Madrigals.
There will I make thee a bed of Roſes,
With a thouſand fragrant poſes,
A cap of ﬂowers, and a Kirtle
Imbrodered all with leaues of Mirtle.
A belt of ſtraw and Yuye buds,
With Corall Claſps and Amber ſtuds,
And if theſe pleaſures may thee moue,
Then liue with me, and be my Loue.
If that the World and Loue were young,
And truth in euery ſhepheards toung,
Theſe pretty pleaſures might me moue,
To liue with thee and be thy Loue.
As it fell vpon a Day,
In the merry Month of May,
Sitting in a pleaſant ſhade,
Which a groue of Myrtles made,
Beaſtes did leape, and Birds did ſing,
Trees did grow, and Plants did ſpring;
Euery thing did baniſh mone,
Saue the Nightingale alone.
Shee (poore Bird) as all forlorne,
Leand her breaſt vp-till a thorne,
And there ſung the dolefulſt Ditty,
That to heare it was great Pitty,
Fie, ﬁe, ﬁe, now would ſhe cry
Teru, Teru, by and by:
That to heare her ſo complaine,
Scarce I could from teares refraine:
For her griefes ſo liuely ſhowne,
Made me thinke vpon mine owne.
Ah (thought I) thou mournſt in vaine,
None takes pitty on thy paine:
Senſleſſe Trees, they cannot heare thee,
Ruthleſſe Beares, they will not cheere thee.
King Pandion, he is dead:
All thy friends are lapt in Lead.
All thy fellow Birds dœ ſing,
Careleſſe of thy ſorrowing.
Whilſt as ﬁckle Fortune ſmilde,
Thou and I, were both beguild.
Euery one that ﬂatters thee,
Is no friend in miſerie:
Words are eaſie, like the wind,
Faithfull friends are hard to ﬁnd:
Euery man will be thy friend,
Whilſt thou haſt wherewith to ſpend:
But if ſtore of Crownes be ſcant,
No man will ſupply thy want.
If that one be prodigall,
Bountifull they will him call:
And with ſuch-like ﬂattering,
Pitty but he were a King.
If he be addiƈt to vice,
Quickly him, they will intice.
If to Women hee be bent,
They haue at Commaundement.
But if Fortune once dœ frowne,
Then farewell his great renowne:
They that fawnd on him before.
Vſe his company no more.
Hee that is thy friend indeede,
Hee will helpe thee in thy neede:
If thou ſorrow, he will weepe:
If thou wake, hee cannot ſleepe:
Thus of euery griefe, in hart
Hee, with thee, dœth beare a part.
Theſe are certaine ſignes, to know
Faithfull friend, from ﬂatt’ring fœ.
